text: CATALEYA RESTREPO, CAT for short, a contained, very centered 10 year old, pretty, but with a toughness, sitti at the dining room table, in a well kept, but modest home with windows that look out over the steep hillside favela attends to her notebook. On the window there are half a dozen beautiful orchid plants. The rare Cataleya orchid. All around there are packed cartons, suitcases. Moving day is at hand.
Cat! Is your homework finished yet?
Working on it Mama. Her mother, taking time off from packing, comes over to Cat, and turns the page of the notebook to reveal the Lar Croft comic and it's copy.
You draw beautifully my love, but if you want to be something in life you have to study.
I am studying Mama. I want to be a super hero. Her mother turns the page back to the lessons.
Better to be a doctor. A lawyer.
Are we going to see Uncle Emilio? 2.
I don't know. Just waiting to hear from your father. Cat looks up at a picture on the wall of the family. Cat her mother, and her father. Her face carries a bit of worry.
I can't believe this. Mid 40'S, a gentleman, calm, courteous, impeccably dresse
At a table, with bottle of liquor and two glasses, Don Luis sits opposite...
Why not? Cat's father. Off to the side, Don Luis's right hand man, MARCO, stands like any right hand, unobtrusive.
Because I love you Fabio. Like a brother.
And I love you Don Luis. Like a brother. He turns to Marco.
Can you believe this guy Marco? We started when we were little...how old were we Fabio?
Ten.
Ten year old bastards stealing apples from the carts in the market. After all we've been through. And now we're on top, he wants to leave...
Luis, I'm going to be honest with you. You remember I had that operation? 3.
That was last year.
Since then, I'm not a hundred percent. And you can't do this thing if you're not a hundred percent. I'm tired.
So you'll take a rest.
You know how many times we should have been dead?
I don't even want to count.
Neither do I. But you gotta think. How lucky we are to still be alive.
Yeah. That's right. We're alive. And what about the future of this  thing we built?
It's yours. It's not my thing any more.
I'm not going to talk you out of it, am I cabron?
I'll always be there for you Luis. Just pick up the phone, I'm there.
I'm gonna hold you to that. You bastard. (EMOTIONAL)
I'm going to miss you.
And I'm going to miss you.
OK. Enough of this sentimental bullshit. Next we'll be crying like two old women. Come on! One last drink, huh? He pours the liquor into the glasses.
To the future. 4. They tap glasses.
Bueno. They shoot the liquor down. Fabio rises.
So. Business is all clear?
All clear. He hands Don Luis a computer disc.
It's all here.
No other copies?
You even have to ask?
Hey. He shrugs. Opens his arms. The two men embrace. Close as brothers.
Adios Marco. Make sure he doesn't get in too much trouble.
Adios Don Fabio. I'll do my best. And with that, Fabio exits the garden. Don Luis watches him, sad to see his friend go. Sighs deeply, pours himsel a whiskey, downs it, turns to Marco.
Kill this motherfucker.

Two men, holding automatics in their laps sit in the back the driver in the front. They see Fabio very contained, calm, walking towards them. The driver turns the engine on. Fabio slips into the passenger seat. The car takes off. Fabio explodes. Smashes the dashboard. Over and over.
This fucker! The motherfucker! He keeps banging the dash. 5.
Not OK Boss?

This bastard thinks I'm an idiot. Playing it all mellow and shit. If he would have yelled and screamed and threatened to kill my whole family, it would have been OK. We  have an hour to get out of here. At most. Off the nervous looks of the guys in the car...
Fabio's car comes to a screeching halt. Fabio exits to three other gunmen, nervous, on edge. The gunmen from the car take defensive positions. Fabio runs up the stairs.
Cat is still at the table drawing, when she hears the screeching of tires, the fast footsteps outside. She sens a storm coming. Fabio bursts in. His wife sees his tensio filled face.
Fabio?
We've got ten minutes.
(PANICKED)
Cataleya, go pack!

I'm packed Mama. Cat is strangely calm, just sits at the table. Watches as Fabio takes the family picture off the wall, pries the frame back, extracts a small chip hidden inside the frame comes over to Cat.
Listen to me my darling. Just in case of anything. This... He holds the chip up.
This is your passport. Do you understand? She nods. He places the chip in her hand, takes a card out of his pocket. 6.
You find yourself alone? You go  to the address on this card. Show it to the man at the front gate.
I don't understand papa.
You don't have to understand. You just have to listen, and remember. As Cat looks at the chip.
As Fabio's men keep a sharp lookout, two SUV's come rolli down the street. Their fingers work the triggers of their weapons. The two SUV's roll up. The blacked out windows roll down.
(polite. smiling) Hola. We want to see Don Fabio.
He's not home.
You mind if we wait?
Your time.
Fabio writes on top of Cat's drawing, rips the page off folds it, puts it in her pocket, removes a medal from aro his neck, drapes it over hers.
And this will keep you safe. Cat looks down at the medal.
An imprint of a flower.

The Cataleya orchid. It comes from one place on Earth. Our place. My mother, your grandmother, used to grow them. Every morning I  would wake up to the sight of them. The smell of them. That's why I named you after them. It reminds us of who we are. 7. He kisses her on the forehead. His wife appears at the doorway with two suitcases.
I'm ready.
The man in the SUV is on the phone.
They said he's not home yet. He listens. OK. OK. He hangs up. Puts his phone back in his pocket. Walks up to Fabio's men.
Change of plans. He pulls out his gun, shoots them point blank.
As they are exiting the house through a rear door, the shots ring out. They see another black SUV rushing up the street.

Back! He pushes his family back inside. Fabio runs to the windo Sees his men on the losing end of a gun battle. As the men fall, and others run up the stairs firing as they retreat toward the front door...
Too late. Get ready! The Mother drops the suitcases and runs to the rear room. Fabio comes over to the unnaturally calm Cat.
I love you very much.
I love you too Papa.
Reaches under the table where Cat is sitting, takes a gun strapped there. Next to the gun is a big knife. And then footsteps, coming fast outside, draw his attenti 8.
Alicia! His wife runs into the room toting two big assed assault rifles. She tosses one to Fabio. Both of them take up shooter's positions facing the door.
Sitting at the table, very still. Watching.

Facing the front door, hands gripping their assault rifle sweat dripping down their faces, chests heaving, waiting, waiting, to blow anyone who comes through the door to kingdom come. But they never get the chance because...

Machine gun fire shatters the windows on both sides of th room, tearing into their bodies before they even get one shot off. Tearing the orchid plants there to shred. Cat watches in mute disbelief, shocked, as her parents bodies are riddled with heavy caliber rounds making them twitch and dance like marionettes on wires. Their blood splattering across the room, across her. And then... Silence. Silence so complete it is deafening in it's absence of any sound. Cat just sits in her chair. And then the door bursts open and four gunmen storm into the room, their assault weapons trained on the only livin  thing in the room. Cat. Marco enters.

You in the kitchen. You, the bedroom. You, the back. The gunmen scatter. Marco has his inquisitive eye on Cat, who does not drop her eyes, impossible to read. One of the GUNMAN strides over to Cat, jams a gun to her head. Cat does not move a muscle. Does not blink.
Examines the frame Fabio dug the chip out of.

head_text.subj: THE GUNMAN WITH THE GUN TO CAT'S HEAD

text: He chambers a round, is about to pull the trigger... 9.
Hey! What are you doing? As the other gunmen begin to tear the house apart, lookin for something, Marco strides over to Cat. The frame in his hand.
Don Luis said kill everyone.
He also said no names.
She won't remember. He is about to pull the trigger.
The gunman stops.
She's a kid.
So what?
What do you mean so what? You take a kid, teach them, they have value. The gunman takes his gun, lifts Cat's lip, looks at her teeth.
I couldn't even get ten bucks for her in the street. The gunman is about to pull the trigger again.
Are you stupid or what? Here. Marco hands him some cash.

Here's twenty asshole. Go do your job. Scowling, the gunman joins the others in ripping the hous apart, looking for something. Marco calmly goes to the fridge, takes out two bottles of water, cracks the caps, sets one down on front of Cat as he sits opposite her. Her hands are in her lap. 10.
(SOFTLY)
Remember me Cataleya? Cat shakes her head no.
I was at your confirmation. My name is Marco, and I was a very good friend of your father. I see he gave you his medal. Alluding to the medal around her neck.
The Cataleya orchid. His symbol. Your name. That's good. This way you will always remember him. (BEAT)
I know this is a terrible thing for you to have seen.  All the while his men are searching, frisking the bodies of the dead, even tearing the heels off their shoes.

Some things are too complicated for a kid to understand. This is one of them. But I am going to try explain it and make it very simple for you. So you understand. Now, you know who Don Luis is? Cat responds, shakes her head yes. Her hand slips imperceptibly under the table.
Touches the handle of the knife taped there.
Of course you do. He was your father's best friend since they're kids. He's like an Uncle to you. You know he has always been good to your family, don't you? Again Cat shakes her head.
This house, the food you eat, the clothes you wear. Even your school fees. All this comes from Don Luis. You know that? Again Cat shakes her head. 11.
But when someone is good to you and you are not good to them back, then bad things happen. Things like... He alludes to the riddled bodies of her dead parents.
This. Cat looks from the bodies and back to Marco, no emotion i her eyes.
I know you are a smart girl. You do well in school. So I know this is not too complicated for you to understand. Am I right? Cat nods.
Good. Now, your father had something that belonged to Don Luis. A little thing. No bigger than... He holds up his thumbnail.
This. Maybe it was in this. He holds up the frame, shows where the chip was dug out o the wood.
Do you know what I am talking about? Cat nods.
Gripping the knife handle.
Excellent. Do you know where it is? Cat nods.
Well, if you give it to me, Don Luis will be very grateful. And very generous. He will make sure that you are clothed, fed, and sent to the very best school. You will have everything you want. (MORE)
But if you don't give it to him, he will be very unhappy. And you see what happens when he is not happy, yes?  Cat nods yes.

So why don't you just give that little thing which belongs to him. Will you do that? Cat hesitates for a moment, and then removes one hand fro underneath the table, her fist closed tight. Marco smiles kindly. He holds out his hand.
You are a smart girl. Marco opens his hand.
And in this life, smart girls get everything they want. What do you want Cat? And just as she is about to open her hand...
Under the table, gripping the handle of the knife taped there.

Just tell me sweetheart...what do you want? In a flash, the knife is whipped out and buried into Marc unsuspecting, open palm. Driven with such force, the knif pierces through the back of his hand, and sticks into the table beneath; pinning his hand. Marco wants to scream but there is so much pain, nothing escapes his throat.
(in his ear) To kill Don Luis!
The men searching look up, and before they can react, Cat races past them.
Get her!

As she runs through the rooms of the house, sprints to th bathroom where one foot hits the toilet, springing her onto the ledge of a very small window. As she looks back she sees the gunmen in hot pursuit. And she jumps, head first. Barely squeezing her small frame through the tiny window. And she drops... Six feet down, onto a ledge, that is just beneath the window. She flattens against the wall, holding onto the medal of her father.

One of the gunman comes to the window, cannot fit through looks out, does not see anybody across, then hears someth beneath him, looks down, sees the tip of a shoe below. Puts his gun out the window, points it down, and....
Lets loose with a barrage from his weapon.
She watches as the bullets split the cement all around he feet. Coming inches from ripping into them. And then the barrage stops.
His clip runs out. And as he fumbles to slam another one in...

She hears the pause. Looks out over the sprawl of houses that stretch up and down the steep hillsides of the favel She looks down at her open palm at the small chip her fat gave her. Pops the chip in her mouth, swallows, leaps over the small divide between her house and the next roof and takes off running.

Gets the clip to fit, sees Cat heading off across the roo out in the open, exposed, vulnerable. He lifts his gun to shoot, when the gun muzzle is slammed up, peppers the ceiling with bullets. The gunman turns to Marco, holding  his bloody rag wrapped hand.
We need her alive!
Cat leaps from one rooftop to another, shinnies down a drain pipe onto another roof. 14.
Jumping down from the window of Cat's home, start to spri across the roof in hot pursuit.
She drops down to another roof, this one filled with a vegetable patch, where an old man is gardening.
Marco exits Cat's house, wrapping his bloody hand tightly with a piece of his shirt.
Go! Go! He orders four more gunmen who have just zoomed up on motorcycles. The souped up rice rockets take off in four different directions.
As she comes off the last rooftop, down into a small alle She sprints across to a small door. She kicks at the door which gives way and enters...

Where a half dozen women are doing laundry by an open tap They look up to the sight of this little girl in the bloo splattered school uniform, do not say a word. And neither does Cat. She just runs through to a small gate on the far side of the courtyard, opens it, and disappears. One of the women casually hangs one of her wet sheets over th gate, hiding it.

They crash through the vegetable garden. The old man deft kicks a rake leaning against the wall. It falls in betwe the rows of tomato vines. When the gunmen sprint through, the first one trips over the rake, goes crashing through the vines, which causes the two men behind him to also trip and fall. The fourth man hurdles his fallen cohorts, bounds over the roof. And the fifth man, looks at the old man. Knows what he has done. Shoots him dead before jumping off the roof.
She races down a steep hill in the crowded favela streets
They enter the laundry yard. The women don't even look up. The gunmen look around, just see laundry hanging from the fence, do not see the hidden door. Race back out.

She runs down a steep alley, filled with people sitting outside their homes, chatting, playing dominoes. At the end of the alley, two motorcycles appear. The ride see Cat, as she sees them. They turn their bikes into the alley...

And bear down on Cat. Cat sprints back up the hill. She goes to escape into one of the open doors, but she finds that one after another the doors have closed shut, the people fled inside. The bikes eat up the hill. Cat's legs are no match for them. It seems she will be caught any second. She ducks down a street where laundry is hung on a concealed metal pipe running the length of the alley. As Cat ducks throug the sheets the gunmen gun their bikes right towards her tear through the sheets...

head_text.subj: AND THE CONCEALED METAL PIPE CATCHES THEM ACROSS THEIR

text: She looks back, to the dead gunmen, disappears over the  hill. AND JUST AS SHE DOES... Marco, in an open top jeep, with three of his gunmen ON BOARD, comes rolling up the road. He sees Cat.
There! The jeep screeches around. Cat dashes down an alley.
As she runs up the alley with it's open sewers running on either side.
The alley is too narrow for the jeep. The men spill out, spring up the alley.
Alive! 16.
She runs up the alley, then ducks down another one. She comes to a ladder that leads up a fence, begins to climb.
Running up the alley, turning into the next one. Where they see the ladder. One of the gunmen pulls out his cell phone.
In the jeep, scouting as it rolls along.
She is running for all she is worth, out of breath, scare
More thugs on bikes, on foot, in cars. They are everywher
She is leaning against a wall on a rooftop, gulping air  when she hears the roar of engines. Looks over the side of the building to see dozens of gunmen flooding the area
Climbing the ladder.
Hearing them coming.
Surrounding a building. Throwing grappling hooks onto the roof ledge.
Seeing the grappling hooks claw onto the roof edge.
Cresting the roof from the ladder.
Rappelling up the side of the building on the grappling ropes.
Flooding onto the roof from both sides. Coming to the spot where Cat was only moments before. To find no Cat. 17. One of the gunmen takes out his cell. Dials.
On the phone.
North! Go North! We're cutting off the southern streets! Marco slams his phone shut. Heads for his car.
North!  The gunmen clear the roof. As the last one leaves, he takes one last suspicious sweep of the roof, cannot figur where this wisp of a girl went to. His eyes briefly focus on the chimney...
Let's go. He clambers over the side of the roof. THE CAMERA STAYS FOCUSED ON THE CHIMNEY.
Cat, holding her breath, listening keenly to the sound of the men departing, is wedged into the chimney, her hands and feet clinging like a lizard to the walls on either side.

Cat comes over the top of a hill, the soot of the chimney mingled with the blood of her parents, staining her dress The doors and windows all along the street are shuttered tight. Her eyes search the curb as she makes her way down the street. When she hears the sound of a vehicle. She looks up to a jeep turning the corner.
In the windshield of the jeep, staring at her.
We got her! Close the net!
She sees Marco. She pauses for a moment, and then does something that stuns even Marco. She starts to run right towards the jeep!
A bit stunned.
What is she doing?
She keeps sprinting toward the jeep. Another jeep appears  over the hill behind her. Starts to come at her.
As his jeep speeds right for her.
As she runs, her eyes go to the right, and it becomes apparent she knows exactly what she is doing. She has a plan. And she executes it. Suddenly, she leaps for the curb and... A SEWER GRATE.
Sees Cat dive to the curb.
As she wriggles her skinny little body down the grate, with barely enough room to squeeze in. But in she does squeeze.

In total disbelief, watching her disappear down the narro slit in the curb. Both jeeps pull up. The men jump out. Marco flattens to the street, peers into the grate, sees Cat staring up at him. Marco takes his gun out. Jams it in the grate...
Empties his clip into the dark. When he runs out of ammo, he peers down again. Cat is gone. The gunmen run to the next sewer grate fire into that one. Marco looks down, no Cat.
Get down there! The gunmen rip the grate out, jump down the hole. 19.
The gunmen, following the beams of their flashlights, go tramping through the muck of the sewers, trying to find Cat. The only living things they find are rats, scurrying across their feet.
(ON PHONE)
We lost her!
He kicks every car in the street in frustration.
The gunmen wait in the sewer, waiting. MARCO V.O. Come back out. The gunmen retreat back the way they came. They do not see someone watching them go.
A small crevice in the sewer wall. Cat has squeezed herse into the crack, almost invisible.
Cars and trucks rumble along a busy thoroughfare.

head_text.subj: A SEWER GRATE CUT INTO THE SIDE OF THE CURB

text: A hand emerges. And then, Cat pulls herself out, into the street.

She stands at the edge of the busy thoroughfare, and look around. She is in the heart of the city. Where tall offic buildings, compete with graceful, classical mansions. In the distance, she sees the hillsides, covered with the twinkling lights of the favelas, two miles, and a world away.
Two Marines stand guard. Looking straight ahead.
Excuse me... 20. The Marine looks down to Cat. Bedraggled, covered in soot and blood and shit. Holding out the card her father gave her.

head_text.subj: THE FACE OF A MIDDLE AGED AMERICAN

text: The American looks at the card Cat gave to the Marine, hands it to another American.
And you say you have something for us? He turns to Cat, who nods yes.
May I see it? Cat takes a beat. Puts her fingers down her throat. And throws up all over the man's desk.

Oh jeez... Cat reaches into the goop on the desk and comes up with the chip. She hands it over to the man behind the desk, who takes a handkerchief out and takes it from her, gingerly. He looks at the chip, looks at Cat.
(REPULSED)
Thank you.
Facts, figures, names, dates, a wealth of information scrolls down.

head_text.subj: PULL BACK TO THE TWO AMERICANS LOOKING AT EACH OTHER

text: We have to record this. Cat does not understand. The second American hits a butto on a remote.
Where did you get this?
My Papa. 21.
And where is your Papa?
Dead.
Did he tell you what this is?
Yes...my passport.
Cat watches out the window as the plane's landing gear drops and the city of Miami spreads out before her in all it's shimmer and glistening glory.

We are making our final approach to Miami International airport. Please fasten your seat belts. She looks down at the medal around her neck. A tear forms in her eye. Rolls down her cheek. Impossible to tell if it is a tear of joy or sadness.

Cat, with a plastic envelope holding her travel documents around her neck, accompanied by an airline rep, walks dow the jetway toward the entrance to the airport, where a MA is standing. Looking directly at her. All the passengers are filing to the left as they leave the jetway, but as Cat and her escort approach the man..
Come with me. He walks to the right.
Cat stands in front of a rotund bureaucrat, with the man who escorted her, handing over her passport.
She's the one?

She is indeed. The Bureaucrat looks at her passport. As Cat glimpses through the slatted window looking out over the Customs floor, where all the other passengers are being processed in long lines. 22.
You must have done something pretty important to get the royal treatment little lady. Cat says nothing. He stamps her passport.
Welcome to America. Cat looks at him, not sure if this is good news or bad news.
Cat looks out the window of the car at the skyline passin by, silent, filled with wonder.

You like music? Cat looks at him, doesn't respond. He turns the radio on. A god awful C&W song comes on. Cat looks at him for a moment, then reaches over, turns the radio off. Goes back to looking out the window.
The car passes a gate with a sign: MISS PORTERS SCHOOL FO GIRLS.
It's been our mission statement since we first opened our doors in nineteen twenty three...

To provide a safe, healthy nurturing environment where young women can get the education they will need to meet the challenges of that amazing adventure called life. How does that sound to you, my dear? Cat does not respond, she just stares out the window.
It's been a long day for her. Here's the check for the year's tuition. He hands over a check. 23.
And the five hundred dollars allowance for the first six months. He hands over a wad of bills.
Which we keep right here... She places the money in an envelope with Cat's name on it and puts the envelope into a drawer.
And give you twenty a week for incidentals. She hands a twenty to Cat. Who takes it without saying a word.
What do we say darling?
Where do I sleep?

Three dozen girls of all ages go about their business. Some do homework on their beds, others do their hair, dan run around. And suddenly, at the sound of a door opening, they all stop and look in the same direction at Cat and the MONITO
Girls, this is your new classmate. Please welcome her and show her the ropes. (TO CAT)

Wake up is at seven. Sweet dreams. She exits. All the girls stare at Cat. No one makes a move. In the silence, you can hear a pin drop, until... The biggest girl in the dorm, a head taller than everyone and twenty pounds heavier, with bully written all over he face, saunters down the aisle right towards Cat. Her name is...
I'm Sherri. And you are?
Very tired. The girls all around twitter. Sherri looks back at them, no good rising on her smirking face. 24.
Well, 'very tired', I'm sure you want to lay down and rest your little head? I do.
There's your bed... She points halfway down the aisle to an empty bed. Cat is about to walk towards it, when Sherri puts a beefy hand i her chest.
But it's gonna cost you. (BEAT)

Twenty dollars. Cat looks at Sherri. Looks at the other girls all hanging on every word, waiting to see what jumps off. Cat considers, then reaches into her jumper and extracts the twenty dollars the headmisstress gave her. Hands it over to Sherri.
A week. Peace has it's price, y'know what I'm saying? Cat says nothing, just stares at Sherri.
Are we clear on that?
Twenty dollars a week. Sherri opens her sweatshirt to reveal a fanny pack. She unzips it, puts Cat's twenty in with a wad of other twenties.
We got a smart one! The other girls hoot and whistle. Sherri removes her hand from Cat's chest.
You can go now. (BEAT)

In peace. Cat still says nothing. She walks up the aisle past all the other girls, who remain silent. It is only after Cat has laid down on her bed, that the laughing and twitterin resumes. 25. Cat stares at the ceiling, her hand reaches inside her jumper, takes out the medal her father gave her. She hold it close in her hand, just lays that way.
All the girls are asleep in their beds. Silence reigns, except for the small cries and sighs of girls asleep.
Her eyes still open, her hand clutching her father's meda She gets up.

Cat makes her way down the hall. At the end of the Hall is a door marked EXIT. But she is not looking at the exit she is looking for something else. And she finds it. A door marked: HEADMISTRESS. Cat tries the door, it is locked. She takes her father's medal from around her neck, and uses it to pop the lock. Looking left and right to make sure the coast is clear, she enters.
Cat tries the drawer where the Headmistress locked her money away. She looks around, takes a letter opener off the desk, pops the drawer, extracts the envelope with her name on it.
Again Cat walks down the darkened hall, looking for anoth door. Finds it marked: INFIRMARY.
Cat walks along the cabinets containing the pharmaceutica until she finds what she is looking for. She smashes the glass door, reaches in, extracts one bottle.

Cat, with four belts slung over her shoulder, the bottle from the infirmary in one in one hand, a cloth in the oth stands over the sleeping Sherri. Cat pours the contents of the bottle out into the cloth. Seals the bottle. Puts it down. Then takes the cloth and  places it over Sherri's sleeping face, ever so gently. 26.
The sun comes up over the horizon, casts it's first rays through the windows of...

The sun hits the faces of the girls. As they wake, they find two very interesting things. 1. A twenty dollar bill on each bed. 2. Sherri fast asleep, her hands and feet tied to the pos of the bed with belts, her shirt pulled up, her money bel gone. And the word THIEF written in magic marker across her stomach. And the drawing of the Cataleya orchid.
A kind faced Hispanic woman, a...
Hola chica, where are we wanting to go today?
Cat, barely up to the window, hands the ticket agent the piece of paper her father gave her. The woman looks at the paper.
Chicago is not next door, you know.
How much? Cat holds up the envelope from the headmistresses office.

The landscape of America passes by through the window of bus. Clutching a new Lara Croft comic, nibbling on a big Mac and fries out of a bag, Cat sees...  The sugar cane harvests in the Florida wetlands. Two big fat black women sitting on the porch of a shack shelling peas in the deep South. The Steel Mills of Pittsburgh fire up. The endless expanse of corn and wheat stretching from horizon to horizon across Ohio. 27. The giant milk barns of Indiana with their hundreds of cows. And finally, sees the great city of Chicago looming in th distance as the bus hurls down the highway towards it.

As seedy as any bus terminal. People bustling, people hustling. A veritable cauldron of humanity bubbling with the good, the bad, the ugly. The predators and the prey. Cat exits into this stew of life, looks around, checks things out. As she is checked out in turn by some pretty sleazy types. Cat ignores the eyes following her, walks up to a dwarf hawking newspapers. Hands him her slip of paper. He point her in a direction.

Cat walks across the neighborhoods of Chicago. Sees the signs in Polish change into signs in Italian, in Spanish, Chinese, Ethiopian. She hands her paper to an Ethiopian cabbie. He points her onward. She walks past bars where black gangbangers watch her pas She hands one her paper, he points her on. She walks past massive churches, synagogues, mosques. She walks past the stately houses of the Gold Coast, alon the deserted stretches of the glam shops on Michigan Aven over the bridges.
Until she comes to...
The denizens of this world look every bit as dangerous as they are. Gangbangers, con artists, trouble waiting to happen at every turn.

Cat, walking down the block as the eyes of everyone she passes follow her. She stops on a street corner. Seems lost. Opposite her a group of men, hanging outside a bar see her. The leader of the group calls her over.
Hey kid. You know what time it is? Cat shakes her head. 28.
It's late, and this is not the kind of place a kid should be hanging out. What are you doing here? Cat hands him her paper. He looks at her, suspicious.
Who are you? Cataleya. The man takes a moment...

Wait here. He disappears up a small alley into the darkness beyond. Cat, not knowing what to do, sits down on the curb, watch street life. She sees... Hookers soliciting men in passing cars. Cops sitting in a patrol car, bored, blase. Men playing craps against a wall. Some very discreet dope deals, more sleight of hand than anything else.
A very bloodied face. Once, twice, three times.
EMILIO RESTREPO, 35, a hard case, fuck with me at your ow risk written all over his face, is about to deliver anoth crushing blow to a poor soul strapped to a chair when...
Emilio. The beating stops, Emilio turns.
There's a girl looking for you.
I'm not interested in a girl right now. He turns back to the task at hand. Cocks his fist. 29.
It's not that sort of thing. She's eight. Again, Emilio stops. The man hands her Cat's paper.
Says her name's Cataleya. This focuses Emilio's attention.
Cat is sitting watching the street, when a pair of legs appear in front of her. Cat looks up to the man who disappeared.
Come with me. He turns abruptly, heads back up the alley.
Cat follows the man through a darkened alley. At interval on either side, dangerous looking men, armed to the teet stand in the shadows. The man opens a door, beckons Cat to enter.

Cat follows the man as he moves down a long hallway. Cat looks into the rooms on either side of the hall as she walks along. In one room, opening out to a trucking bay, TV sets are being unloaded into a big warehouse full of stolen merchandise. In another room, guns are being serviced. Lots of guns, hand guns, assault rifles. Big artillery.
Hey! Cat's attention is drawn away from the room with the guns to the Man holding a door open for her at the very end of the hall.

Cat enters an office with three women working on computer Looks like any other business office. At the sight of Cat, the women get up and exit, closing the door behind them. Cat is left alone. She looks around the office, when the sound of a door opening behind her. She turns to Emilio. Who approaches her cautiously, scrutinizing her. 30.
Cataleya? Now it is Cat who hesitates.
Uncle Emilio? Emilio covers his mouth, seems rocked.
Madonna! I thought you were dead! He crosses himself.

I thought you were all... Cat stands stock still. Emilio takes her up in his arms lifts her, crushes her to his chest. Cat remains suspende emotionless for a moment. And then, for the first time emotion, real emotion, washes across her face. Her lower lip begins to tremble. Tears well up in her eyes. She bursts into tears.
You're safe now. All the emotion, the fear, the anger that she has kept locked away deep inside, rushes to the surface in one massive wave.
You're safe.
The sun peeks over the horizon, spreading the fog infused light coming off Lake Michigan across the sleeping city a it ascends in the sky.
One beam of sunlight slips through the narrow crack betwe a window and the shade covering it.
The ray of sunlight washes across Cat's sleeping face. She wakes slowly. Her eyes open after a long sleep. For a moment she does not remember where she is.

Cat looks around the clean, orderly bedroom as she gather her thoughts. Her eyes move around the room. It is a boy's room. 31. With models of soldiers, futuristic warriors, a big poste of Al Pacino as Tony Montana in SCARFACE. A poster with every imaginable type of assault rifle.
Emilio sits reading the financial section of the morning  paper over what seems to be the remains of a very hearty breakfast. An elderly woman, grandmotherly, fills his coffee cup.
Gracias mama. A noise turns both of them to the doorway and Cat.
Good morning.
Buenos diaz Cara. Come. Sit. I'll make you some eggs. Mama caresses her face, her eyes glisten with a grandmother's love. Kisses her on the forehead, lovingly whispers into her ear.
You have your mother's beautiful eyes. Don't be scared. This is your home. Slowly, hesitantly, Cat makes her way across the kitchen to the table, where she sits opposite Emilio, tentative.
When was the last time you slept?
I don't know. A long time ago.
Well good. A growing body needs sleep. When I was your age I would sleep half the day. I don't know if it helped with the growing, but I was well rested for whatever came after.
Whose room is that?
My son. Your cousin.
Where is he? 32.
He's dead. His voice holds anger, not sadness.
Killed?
Yes.
By who?
No one who is still alive. Mama comes over, puts a plate of eggs in front of her. As she begins to wolf down the food. He holds up the page of her drawing, the one her Father put his address on.
You are very talented. Is this what you want to be? An artist?
I used to want to be like Lara. A super agent. Shoveling more food into her mouth.
Not anymore? Chewing, Cat shakes her head.
And now?
(matter of fact) I want to be a killer. She keeps shoveling food in her mouth. Emilio looks up at his mother, who crosses herself. Cat finishes the last mouthful, looks up.
Can you help? Emilio blinks once.
Sure.
Emilio walks Cat down the street. He is carrying a kids book bag. 33.

The good news is your father bought you your life with what he gave you. The bad news is Don Luis was playing both sides, and has disappeared. You tore down everything he spent years building up with that little chip. It is something he will not forget. There is a law in this thing of ours. If someone does you, the revenge goes all the way down the line. Women, children, Grandmothers, dogs, cats. No exceptions.
Are you trying to scare me?
I am trying to educate you.
The PRINCIPAL watches Emilio count the money out.
Normally we don't accept students in the middle of the academic year, but under the circumstances, losing her parents in that tragic car accident... Cat looks out the window, saying nothing.
Here. He hands a list over to Cat. Who keeps looking out the  window.
These are the school supplies you'll need. Emilio takes them.
She's still in a bit of shock.
Of course. See you Monday Cataleya. Such a pretty name. She keeps looking out the window. 34.
As Emilio walks along, with Cataleya, reading the list of supplies.
We'll get all this stuff, then go over to this little place I know down on Maxwell street for some of these hot dogs the Polish people make here. He turns left at the cross street...
You like hot dogs? He looks down, sees no Cat. Looks back to see Cat walking in the opposite direction.
Hey! Cat keeps going.
Hey! He hurries, catches up with her.
Where you going?
I've already been to school. I told you what I want to be. You don't want to help me, fine. I'll do it myself. She walks off. Emilio grabs her.

Chica. Any idiot can be a killer. Look! Emilio draws a .357 magnum pistol from his shoulder holst and empties the entire clip into the front of a car comin down the street. The car careens off the road, smashes a fire hydrant, crashes through a plate glass window of a shop across the street. The water from the hydrant shoot twenty feet in the air. Emilio holsters his gun.
You want me to teach you to be a killer? No problema. I'll teach you. But you'll be dead in five years. (MORE)

If you want to be a killer, and survive, you have to be a smart one. You have to know things besides how to pull a trigger. You have to know how the world works. How people think. You got to learn to be psychological. That I cannot teach you, unless you learn the basics at school. Got it? Cat glares at him.

Now what's it going to be? He holds out the gun in one hand, and the schoolbag in th other. Cat hesitates for a moment. Takes the schoolbag from Emilio. Then takes his hand, and they walk off together as police sirens announce the arrival of cruiser and people pour out of the school and the surrounding stores. As they put distance between the chaos and themselves.  But I still want to be a killer.
(SIGHING)
Cabron!
A sleepy California town on the way to nowhere.
A police cruiser sits on a quiet street, right off a wide avenue. Main street. There is no traffic either way. The nose of the cop car juts out just off the street.
Two cops are sitting, peeling back the wrappers on their burgers. coP 1 So then I suggest, y'know, we buy some things to spice it up a bit.

Define things. 36. As they nibble and talk, they pay scant attention to a se of headlights coming up the broad avenue. coP 1 A garter belt, some of those stockings that come up the thigh...it's fourteen years. Know what I mean? The lights come closer...

Yeah. No matter how much you like steak, sometime a lamb chop is not a bad thing. The lights shine right into the car.  coP 1 Exactly. Only then, when the lights are directly on them, do the cops turn to see a car heading right toward their front end. coP 1 What the...
The front end of the cop car gets sheared right off by th impact. Glass shatters, metal crunches, airbags explode!

The other car. The drivers door opens. A vodka bottle falls out, clinks to the sidewalk. And a moment later, two legs emerge from the car. Two very long, very shapely legs. Legs that never end. In very high heels, and a very short mini skirt. And the face on top of it, framed by a mane of wild hair, is drop dead think-you-have-died- and-gone-to-heaven gorgeous. The whole package reads SUPERMODEL. And by the way she is weaving when she stands and the bottle at her feet, the read is; very drunk supermodel. Who looks at the crumpled police cruiser, looks into the windshield of the cruiser at the stunned cops, and says in the most sweetly drunk voice...

Oops... The cops can't believe this. They regain their wits and bolt out of the car. coP 1 That's all you have to say? Oops? And, ever so sensually, she starts to laugh. The cops look at each other, perplexed. And she keeps laughing. 37. The cops get pissed. coP 1 Funny? ...and she keeps laughing. coP 1  Wanna laugh you crazy bitch? I'll give you something to laugh about! And even when they slam her to the hood of the car, jam her hands behind her back, and slap the cuffs on, she kee laughing, and laughing.

head_text.subj: WHERE A VERY FAMILIAR MEDALLION ON A CHAIN HANGS BETWEEN
HER EXPOSED CLEAVAGE. A MEDALLION ENGRAVED WITH THE
IT IS CAT, ALL GROWN UP.

text: A quiet night in the small station. Cat stands in front of the booking desk, so drunk the two cops have to hold her up. A surveillance camera over the desk innocuously records everything. Cat keeps her head down, her face, obscured by her mane of hair. As the SERGEANT goes through her purse, finds...
No license, no registration. No ID except a library card. Well Ms... He reads off the library card.
Valarie Phillips in addition to all that...you're being charged here with DUI, destruction of police property, driving the wrong way on a two way street...
Is that it?
Unless you can think of anything else you should be charged with.
(TIPSY)
Wearing no panties? 38. The Sergeant and the arresting cops holding her up give her a long look, as do any of the other cops in ear shot whose eyes go to her very short skirt.
That's not a crime.
Thank goodness. And she teeters over, passes out cold right on the Sergeant's desk.

Take her in the back, lock her up, put a cup of coffee in with her. Let her sleep it off, we'll book her tomorrow. The two cops who booked her drag her out. As they do, the Sergeant and the two other cops on duty lean over to try and get a look up her very long legs and her very short skirt.

Three black SUV's, with blacked out windows, come rolling up to the station. The doors open and a dozen U.S. MARSHA jump out. Vigilant, forming a cordon around one of the vehicles, out of which comes a hand cuffed, kevlar wearin hard as nails MAFIA type. GENNARO RIZZO. The Marshal's surround him, guns bristling, on the look out for any danger, and hustle him towards the doors of the police station.
The station doors slam open. Marshal's barge in. The HEAD MARSHAL approaches the surprised Sergeant on the des flashes his credentials.
US Marshal Warren. We have Gennaro Rizzo here on an overnight.
Who?
Rizzo. The Mafia guy? On the way to testify up in San Francisco tomorrow? They didn't notify you?
Hold on a second. He rifles through some papers. Finds one. 39.
Here we go. Says here you're not expected until tomorrow.
Never expect the expected Sergeant. (to his men) Secure this place.
The Marshals come down the cell block, checking everythin out. They pass Cat in her cell, passed out cold, her long legs and short skirt slows their progress a bit. After a long look, they move on.
Rizzo is pushed into a cell. The door is slammed and locked.
One man here. Two more outside the front door. Everyone else on the perimeter, in teams of two. He hands out thermos bottles.
It's a caffeine kinda night fellas. Eyes open.
A lone cop passes Cat's cell, doing the nightly rounds. As soon as he is gone...

Cat's eyes snap open. She sits up, moves with the efficiency and determination of someone who has not has a drop of alcohol. She takes a spoon from the coffee cup left for her, reaches into her mane of hair and extracts small pin. She inserts the pin into the keyhole of the door, jiggles it. The door pops open.  Cat exits the cell, takes a broom leaning in the corner and keeping her eye on the camera above the door, she sli along the wall, until she is just under the camera. She uses the broom handle to tilt the camera up just a bit.
One lone cop sits in front of the various monitors. He does not notice that one tilts slightly up, points toward a blank wall. 40.
Cat, under the camera, unlocks the second door, slips out

Cat comes into the hall where several vending machines lean against the wall. On the far side is a door marked: ELECTRICAL. She is about to head for it, when she hears a door open at the far end of the hall.

At the far end of the hall. A cop comes in, looks down the hall. Where Cat was standing he sees only the vending machines. He heads right for the machines. Puts coins in the machine, waits for his food.

Where Cat is pressed hard against the flat surface, inche from the cop. The sandwich falls, the cop retrieves it, moves off, exit down the hall. Cat waits until she hears the door shut on the far end of the wall. She crosses quickly to the door across the way, enters.
Revealing the electrical control panel for the station.

Cat stands on a narrow shelf, undoes the last screws on a vent in the ceiling with a screwdriver from the tool boar on one wall. Cat drops down, opens the electrical control panel on th wall, studies it for a moment, finds the switch she is looking for, then turns to the wall of tools, plucks some wire, a cutter, a spring. Cat sets to work on a jury rigged mechanism with the item at hand. When she is finished, she tugs at the waist band of her mini skirt, and little by little she stretches a thin dun colored leotard suit over her whole body. She takes a small plastic vial, fills it with some water from the tap, and sets it, just so, above the device she has constructed. The device is hooked to the switch she selected, a small weight hangs from the bottom of it by a wire. She sets the water container just so over the spoon from her cell. The water begins to drip a drop at a time. She closes the panel door, sets her digital watch. Hoists herself up to the vent in the ceiling, and is gone. 41.
Water dripping into the spoon a drop at a time.

Once inside the grate, Cat takes one of the buttons off her blouse and presses the top of it. The button becomes a pin light, which she clasps between her teeth, starts t crawl on her stomach, pulling herself along by her elbows and her wriggling hips and knees, the light still between her teeth.

As she moves through the maze of ducts. On the way, she peers through the grates in each ceiling, down into one cell after another, catching various views of inmates asl as she passes over them. Until she comes to a ventilation fan blocking the way. The fan blades go round and round. Cat looks at her watch, looks at the fan.
And Cat's jury rigged device. The water has almost filled the spoon, one more drop, one more drop.
The digital counter goes from 4 to 3 to 2 tol...
The last drop of water drips into the spoon, the spoon tips, tugging on the wire, the wire trips the switch it i connected to, the whole device comes apart, the separate pieces fall to the floor.
The fan stops. The blades slow.
The sergeant at the desk hears the ventilation system go off.
Hey Doyle! He calls to one of the other cops on duty.
Go take a look at the breaker on the ventilation system, will ya? Doyle moves off. 42.
Cat watches the blades of the vent fan slow. When they have completely stopped she starts to move herself throug the very narrow space between the now stilled blades, fee first.
Doyle enters the room, opens the electrical panel. The spoon, the weight, the spring, and the wire, fall to the floor. Doyle looks at them curiously for a moment.
Cat is half way through the fan blades.
Doyle looks at the switches, going down the printed list on the door, trying to locate the right one.
Cat is almost through.
Doyle finds the switch that corresponds to the ventilatio system.
Cat's neck passes through the fan blades. Slow going.
Doyle hits the switch for the ventilation system.
Cat is just through, when the blades start moving, brush against her forehead, as she makes it to the other side with no time, and no room to spare.
Cat comes to a vent, looks down, begins to loosen the ven screws.
Cat drops down into a bathroom. Looks at her watch. Sits down, waiting.
Rizzo is asleep in his cell. The Marshal on duty finishes his coffee. Looks at Rizzo. 43. Then walks over to the door at the end of the wall. He hits a buzzer on the wall.
The cop manning the bank of monitors, wakes up, sees the Marshal in the monitor.
(OVER INTERCOM)
Gotta pee. The monitor hits a button.
The door buzzes open. The Marshal passes through.
The Marshal pushes the bathroom door open. Enters.
The Marshal finishes peeing, zips himself up. Turns. Right into a devastating reverse wheel kick.
The cop on duty hears a buzz, looks up to the bank of monitors, and sees the Marshal standing at the door. Thinking nothing of it, he hits the buzzer.
Cat, propping the unconscious Marshal up, hides behind him. As the door buzzes, she maneuvers the body around, pushes through. On the other side, she drops the body, and takes his gun.
On the monitor it looks like the Marshal is passing throu
Rizzo is half asleep, when the barrel of a gun taps him o the head. He opens his eyes slowly to...
Unbutton your shirt.
What...?
Now. 44. Rizzo looks over to where the Marshal is passed out cold on the floor. He does as he is told.
Who the hell are you?
Not room service. She pumps four bullets into his head.
The four shots reverberate throughout the station.
Two patrols of two Marshal's each hear the shots.
The monitor wakes up.
Cops and Marshal's, guns drawn, come running.
The knocked out Marshal comes to. Finds a gun in his hand Doesn't get it, until he looks over to see Rizzo, with hi face blown off.
The door flies open and the Marshal's and cops come pouri through, to find the Marshal with the gun in his hand and the dead Rizzo.
Drop it!! The Marshal is frozen, totally confused.
Drop it, Joe!!!!! More guns. More confusion. Tension beyond the moon.
I didn't do it! 45.
Drop it!!!! The Marshal drops his gun.
On the floor!
Call a bus! FROM THE POV OF SOMEONE ELSE.
through the vent over the cell. Sees the wobbly confused Marshal with the gun in his hand, hears feet com Cat looks fast.
Cat comes She looks stationed Cat takes
climbing out of a ventilation duct onto the roof. out over the side of the building. Marshal's outside are running into the building. off running.
The cops are cuffing the Marshal.
Guys! I didn't do it!!!
Ambulance on the way! Another Marshal is checking Rizzo.
He's gone.
Search the place!
Cat is running as fast as she can.
Cops and Marshals are running through every room, checkin  everywhere.
Cat reaches another air vent, so about to pry it off when she hears... 46.
Cops running up the stairs, headed for a door above them.
Cat hears the door begin to open. She bangs her high heel together. And two blades come out of the front. She sees the door knob turning. She runs for the roof's edge.
The cops burst through the door to...
The cops pour onto the roof, looking around, guns drawn.

head_text.subj: CAT ON THE SIDE OF THE BUILDING

text: Clinging to the wall like a gekko. The dun colored wall blending with her dun colored suit. How is she doing this
The blades fitted into the seam between the bricks. Her fingertips clinging to the small lip on the bottom of the roof's edge.
The cops look around the roof.
She holds there listening to the noise above. Hears noise below, looks down to see...
Cops searching the alley below.
Hanging to the edge of the building. Listening, watching.
The cops, finding nothing, head back out the door. A mome later...
Cat's hand reaches up.

When one hand has a firm grasp on the roof ledge, she let go with the other hand and grasps the ledge, extracts the blades from the brick seams, and swings herself up on the roof. As her shoes dislodge, some mortar comes loose and falls below.
The crumbling mortar falls on the head of one cop, he loo down, sees the crumbly gravel, looks up, sees nothing.
Cat lands on the roof, lays still.
He examines the gravel, looks up again. And then moves on.
Cat pries the vent cover off, slips in.
Cops are checking every cell in the men's block.
Cat is crawling along as fast as she can.
The cops come to the entrance of the woman's cell block.
Cat comes to the vent in the hallway.
The cops open the door to the women's cell block.
Cat runs. Begins to pull at her leotard.

The cops look at the women's cells, heading right toward Cat's. As they reach Cat's, the same cop who did the roun at the beginning of the night looks into her cell. Cat is laying on her side, away from them, dead asleep, in the same position she was when the cop first checked on her. The cops pause for a moment, then move on.
Her eyes are wide open. She listens for the outer door closing, and then she breathes out, relieved.
An ambulance pulls up, along with the Marshal contingent in their SUV's. The Marshal's spill out of the SUV's as a gurney with a corpse is wheeled into the morgue.
As the Marshal's stand around, the Police Coroner begins to unbutton the shirt of Rizzo the corpse.
What the fuck?
On Rizzo's chest the word TRAITOR is written in thick bla letters. And above them, a drawing of the Cataleya orchid The Marshal's knows what this is.
Holy shit! Call Ross.
The door of a small jet opens and MARCUS ROSS, 48, a kee eyed, no nonsense all business FBI agent, followed by a team of similarly focused men and women, exits down the stairs to...
Agent Ross?
Where is he?
At the hospital.
Let's go.
Reporters are gathered, trying to gain access. The police are keeping them out.
Over the clamor of reporters outside, Cat is just finishi with her finger printing, wipes off as much of the ink as she can. The Sergeant hands over her library card.
I shouldn't drink. 49.
No you shouldn't.
I'm so so sorry.
Tell it to the judge at your hearing in ten days.
What's going on out there? Alluding to all the commotion she sees through the window looking out into the main room.
Nothing. Fill out the forms and you can go.  Really?
Really. We need to get things organized. But don't worry, the judge will send you back, for sure.
I probably deserve it. He hands her a sheaf of papers and a pen. As the pen hits the paper.
Ross, with his team standing off his shoulder, looks down at the stomach.
Same handwriting. Same flower. It's him. Let's see the location.
Cat hands the paper work over to the sergeant.
You're lucky no one was hurt.
I would have never forgiven myself. Keeping her back to the security camera overhead, Cat collects her things and exits. As the door closes... 50. A DOOR TO AN SUV OPENS...
Ross exits the SUV to the crowd of reporters.
Is it Rizzo? Was it an assassination? Are there any clues? Is it true a Marshal did it?
No comment. Ross sees cops coming and going from the station. He turn to the Marshal with him.
You didn't lock it down?
It was after the fact. I didn't think... Ross cannot believe what he is hearing.
Do it. Now. No one in or out.
Exiting the station. Ross and his team sweep past her.
OK! That's it. No one in or out! Lock down! Cat just keeps walking, right past Ross, who heads into the station as the cops try to keep the reporters at bay.

Walking away from the pandemonium she is leaving behind. As it recedes over her shoulder, she picks at her fingers where the fingerprinting ink has stained them. Her prints come off! She drops the fake prints down a sewer and keep walking.
Ross scrutinizes Rizzo's cell as his team takes prints, photos, sweeps the cell for evidence.
I want to see paper on everyone in and out of the station in the last twenty four hours. He looks up to the end of the hall. 51.
And I want the tapes from the  security cameras.
Cat extracts a knapsack from the locker, heads for the woman's bathroom.
Cat tugs at her hair. The wild mane comes off to reveal her straight hair, which she pulls back in a pony tail. She begins to strip out of her mini skirt.

Cat dressed in jeans, a scuffed leather jacket, a basebal cap, with the brim pulled low over her eyes, with her pon tail sticking out of the back, the knap sack on her shoulder, waits on line to board the bus. She keeps her back to the security camera, has her phone to her ear. A number is ringing.
Emilio, fifteen years older, is watching a soccer game, picks up the phone. In the kitchen, Mama is cooking.
Are we good?
Cat moves up the line to board the bus.
We're good.
When are you back?
Day after.
I have something.
The morning after OK?
Can't wait to see you Cara. 52.
Say hello to Mama. He looks over to Mama at the stove, who waves over her shoulder.
Mama says hello back. He hangs up, goes back to his game.
Cat boards the bus. The doors close behind her. As the camera ZOOMS up, and the bus pulls out onto the road... ROSS V.O. See?
Ross is pointing up at the camera Cat tilted.
He tilted the camera just enough so the angle would catch the guard, not who was holding him. He turns to his team.
Twenty two murders in four years all with the same M.O. The word, the flower. He's sending a message, for sure. And I'm beginning to think it's not to us.
But we're the only ones with the information.
And we're not getting anywhere with it, are we? No one on the team can dispute this. It occurs to Ross..

If the message is not for us, let's make sure the one it's intended for gets it. I want you to put it out to the press. Splash it across every newspaper, every magazine. National. I want eyeballs on it coast to coast. Monitor it. Let's see if anything comes back. 53.
A Lincoln town car comes down the leafy, quiet street of well kept homes. Stops at a gate guarded by two men, who wave him through.

The car ends up in front of a very impressive house, whic sits at the end of a long driveway. Toward the era of the walled property, a garage, and a guest house. MR. RICHARD in a suit and tie, looking like a proper mid level government official, or a lawyer, exits, newspaper in han As he approaches the front door, Richard looks over to se two more guards, off to the side. He nods to them, knows them. They nod back. Richard approaches the front door, knocks. While he is waiting, he looks down at the paper. The door opens.
Mr. Richard... Richard looks up to a fifteen year older Marco.
Been a long time.
Yes it has Marco. How's the hand? Marco holds up his scarred hand.
Only hurts when it's humid.
Should've let us relocate you to Arizona instead of New Orleans.
The Boss likes it humid.
There it is then.
He's waiting for you. Richard enters. The door closes.
Don Luis stares out a bay window, drink in hand.
Hello Luis. 54. Don Luis turns.
Hello Mr. Richard.
I brought you the morning paper. He holds the paper up. CLOSE ON A PICTURE OF DEAD RIZZO ON THE FRONT PAGE.
I've seen it.
And...?
Coincidence.
Coincidence? Twenty two times? A flower that only grows in one place on earth? That used to be the calling card of...what was his name? Your former partner? The one who did your wet work?
Fabio. Fabio Maria Restrepo. But I don't understand? Why come here with this?
Because when we find the end of a string we like to know where it begins.
String? Now we are talking about string? I'm not a tailor.

Don Luis. Let's cut to the chase here, OK? When the Agency extracted your ass from Colombia fifteen years ago, and set you up here, we let you resume your business when what we should have done was lock you up for life. In exchange, you were supposed to keep the information flowing.
And I have. 55.
Not much, and not for a very long time.
And this is what you traveled all the way down here to tell me?

No. What I traveled all the way down here to tell you, is there's a limit to our patience. The CIA is not an amusement park. There are no free rides. Everyone pays their way. And you, my friend, have not.
OK OK. What would you want? He slaps the newspaper down with the picture of Rizzo.
I had nothing to do with this. I  swear.
Then find out who does. As he goes to leave.
And Don Luis, don't play the innocent with us. It won't sit well with my bosses if we find out you had anything to do with this. Have a good day. Richard exits.
Richard walks to his car, observed by...
She's talking to us.
It could be anyone. Don Luis reaches out, fast as a Cobra, grabbing Marco by the lapel, pulling him close.
Idiot! I told you. Everyone dead. Down to the dog. (MORE)
You screwed up the first time. Now go fix it. Find her. (BEAT)
Before she finds us.
Cat steps off the bus. Looks around to...

The total full on crush of people that a major metropolit bus terminal holds. She sees a surveillance camera tucked in a corner. She pulls the brim of her hat low over her  eyes, takes off into the crowd.
Cat comes to a non descript high rise. She enters.

Cat enters a completely bare bones dwelling, there is nothing that identifies the person who lives here. White bare walls, a table with one chair, a single bed. Along one wall, a cabinet. On the window sill a single Cataleya orchid. Cat waters the orchid. Cat opens the cabinet to three computer screens. Two of them are divided into quarters and show various views of the building entrance, the lobby, the stairway, the elevator, the hallway. The third screen is dark, until Cat hits a button and mus fills the apartment. Music with a heavy sensual back beat French Rap. Ooh la la. And the screen pulses and glows in time to the beat. Cat's body responds to the music, moving sexy, her shoulders rolling, her hips swaying.

Cat sashays across the open space, a stripper strutting her stuff; shedding, first her blouse, then her jeans, he lingerie, until, by the time she reaches a free standing opaque cylinder of a shower with an opaque shower curtain she is completely nude. She enters the shower. Turns on the water. Like a snake shedding a skin, she lets the water divest her of everything that came before. ROSS V.O. Since each and every one of the victims was a professional bad apple...

head_text.subj: A PICTURE OF RIZZO BEING PINNED TO A WALL

text: We've narrowed motive down to payback or preemptive.
Ross has just pinned up Rizzo's picture on a wall filled with twenty two other deceased, all with words and a CATALEYA ORCHID imprint on their stomach's. He turns to face his team.
Rizzo here... He points to Rizzo on the wall.
The most recent, was done to keep him from talking. Alexa Milshinova... Points to a gorgeous dead woman with the word GRIFTER on her stomach.

...made a career of getting intimate with big stakes gamblers out of Vegas and then taking them off and sending them to meet their maker. D'Angelo James... Points to a huge black man with USURPER written in white letters across his chest.
...tried to take over the heroin trade in Houston from.. He points to two Mexicans, identical twins, one with PAY written on his chest, the other with the word BACK...

The Gemini cartel. Their crimes are self explanatory, if you can read. Now I know some of you are thinking whoever is doing this makes less work for mother. And since there's no collateral damage, why are we wasting valuable manpower and resources on the case? And since until now, there has never been a clue to go on, why go on? But with this last killing... He holds up a stack of folders from his desk. 58.
We have one. As we go to the video tape. He hits a button and the video replay of Cat walking the unconscious guard through the door.
We can't see the assassin, but we can see... He freezes the tape. Points to the time mark on the tape.
The time. 2 AM. Which means our perp was in the station at...I don't have to spell it out for you. He begins to hand the folders out.

These are the names, phone numbers and addresses of everyone with a pulse who entered that police station before two AM. Cops, criminals, clerks, janitors. Everyone. One of them is our target. I want each of you to locate the ten people in the folder you've been given. I want a complete dossier on every one of them for the last ten years of their lives. Run down every lead. Check out every story. Our killer is out there. And we're going to find him. Before he kills again. THE CITY OF CHICAGO. As an elevator train rumbles by below...
An elevator train rumbles by above.
A car parking. And DANNY DELANEY, preoccupied, a pleasant easy going, good looker at 28, closes the door, and walks to the entrance of his low slung apartment building. He enters.
Danny puts his key in the door, finds that it is unlocked He pauses, then enters. 59.
Danny enters his darkened apartment. Goes to turn on the switch...
Don't move. Danny's hand freezes. He stands very still.
Take off your shirt.
Do I have to?
Now. Danny complies.
Turn around. He does. To darkness. And then, a match is struck, a candle is lit. Standing before him, in garters, thigh highs, a very sexy bra, and fuck me pumps is...
Hello Danny.
Hello Jennifer. Cat closes to an inch of him.
You should have called.
Why?
I could have been out.  I have a key.
I could have been late. She begins to kiss him, lightly around the mouth.
I've got nowhere to go.
It's just... 60. Just what? She keeps kissing him, lightly on the neck...
You show up whenever you want to...
And then we have the most incredible sex. (BEAT)
Ever.
I know. I'm just saying... He fumbles for the words.
Wouldn't you like to go to dinner sometime? She keeps nibbling.
Uh-uh. This taste good enough.
Or a movie? Licking him.
No. They put me to sleep.
So let's pop in a DVD and you can spend the night here? She stops. Looks him in the eye.
Would you like the key back?
No. I just want to get...I don't know...
Closer? She resumes nibbling on his neck.
Yes. Closer. She runs her nails down his chest, slowly, teasing. Her hand finds his groin. What she finds makes her smile. 61.
Is this close enough?
(SMILES)

...Yes. She gently lowers his hands to his sides, holds them ther Kisses him deeply. Pushes him down onto the floor. And lowers herself on top of him. A small moan escapes his lips as she takes him inside her.
Danny wakes. His face holds the smile of the memory of the night before. He turns his head, lazily. The pillow beside him is empty.
Jen...? Cat is gone. Danny's smile fades.
Emilio walks down the stairs, carrying a shopping bag.  TRACK WITH HIM ALONG THE STREET. Until he comes to a Laundromat.
Emilio loads laundry from the shopping bag into a machine puts in the coins, then sits down on a bench to watch the cycle. Seems to talk to himself.
Safe? And then we see he is talking to...
On my end. You?
Safe.
What do we have? Emilio takes a manila envelope out of the bag. Places it on the seat next to him. Cat picks it up, looks through it. 62.
You remember the guy who was in the news for running that Ponzi scheme about a year ago?

head_text.subj: A MAGAZINE PULLED FROM THE ENVELOPE

text: The cover features WILLIAM WOOGARD, 45, the most unassumi baldheaded, pudgy faced man, a nerd. Under the headline: PREDATOR.

He disappeared fifty billion dollars. The money was never recovered. Skipped out and bought himself citizenship on some shit hole of a Caribbean island that calls itself a country with no extradition laws. Lot of very pissed off people lost everything. Cat goes to get up.
There's something else. He slaps the newspaper down with Rizzo's picture on the front page.
How long has this been going on?
(BLUFFING)
Not long.
The paper says twenty two. All like this. Tell me why.
No reason.
Since you're a kid, you don't do anything for no reason. Don't play dumb, it insults me.
I've got to get ready. As she goes to rise, Emilio grabs her hand.
It's not just you in this. It's me, Mama. 63.
Tio. You're removed. You book the work, you collect the fees...

I watch your ass. Each and every job, I vet, I double vet. For every one I book you, I turn down five, ten. I promised to keep you safe. I KEEP YOU SAFE. Cataleya. It's a full time job, no matter what you think. Those pictures...they freaked me out. OK? I didn't realize...
I come to you at nine. I say I  want to be a killer. What kind of kid makes a career choice like that unless they have something on their mind. (BEAT)
I live for the day that the blood of the son of bitch who did my parents drips in the gutter. Stop playing the innocent with me. You know this. Forever.
Sure. Of course. But the way you're playing it. They even have a name for you. The Tag killer. I would have stopped it a long time ago. Had I known about this.
Why?
Because I love you. Cat smiles. A smile that could melt ice in winter. But a knowing smile. A 'Don't bullshit a bullshitter' smile.
If you do, you would never have let me get involved in the first place. The truth of her words deprive him of his. She kisses him him on the forehead.
I love you too. And she exits, leaving Emilio more concerned. He looks down at the picture. CLOSE ON THE ORCHID WHICH MORPHS INTO... 64.

head_text.subj: A REAL CATALEYA ORCHID ON A COMPUTER SCREEN WITH THE WORD
CATALEYA BEING TYPED IN THE SEARCH BAR

text: Ross is at his computer, staring at the screen and the orchid, alongside a map of Colombia and the specific reg where the Cataleya is found. He thinks.
OK. Let's try...organization... He types. Data comes up. And what he sees stuns him... A folder marked CIA: CONFIDENTAL. ACCESS DENIED.
(FRUSTRATED)
Fuck... OVER THE SOUND OF CHIMES...

A ramshackle warehouse, it's windows streaked opaque with years of dust and grime, surrounded by a fence, and a wee garden which is home to dozens of the most unique wind chimes of all sizes and shapes, made from scrap metal. And two of the biggest, most ferocious dogs on Earth, lay on their sides, asleep. The dog's ears perk up; hearing something we don't, a low growl begins to rumble deep in their throats. The gate to the garden begins to open, and like a shot the dogs are up, hurling themselves toward the opening gate, eyes flashing, barking loud enough to scare the dead back to life, fangs bared, ready to kill. And then they stop cold when they see who it is coming into their domain.
Holding two very full shopping bags.
Hi guys. And the dogs jump all over her, licking her.
Hey! Hey! She pets them, plays with them.
OK. OK. Now sit. 65.  The dogs obey her in a heartbeat, sitting expectantly. Not making a sound.
Now let's see what good boys you can be. She reaches into one of the shopping bags, pulls out two roasts!
Top cut sirloin. Which she puts down on the ground. The dog's eyes go to the chunks of meat.
Nice, huh? The dogs can barely contain themselves.
Red, juicy, delicious. The dogs whimper in anticipation.

Stay. She picks up the shopping bags, and heads for the ramshac warehouse. The dogs moan, but do not move, their eyes going from the meat to Cat. Cat reaches the door. Turns. Sees the dogs looking at her.
Good boys. (BEAT)
Eat. The dogs pounce. Each one grabs a roast and tears into the meat with ferocious, pent up glee. Cat smiles at the sight, enters the warehouse.

The warehouse, is filled with piles of rusting scrap meta the cannibalized carcasses of cars, trucks, shipping containers, welding equipment, hammers tongs, all sorts o tools. In the corner is one fully built truck, a big red  monster with huge demolition fenders. This is home to OLD PEPE, an ancient, blind man, who is working away, building yet another set of oversized chime out of scrap metal.
Hola Cataleya. 66.
Hola Pepe. I guess the boys gave me away.
Anyone else? The barking would only have stopped when their screaming began. You spoil them.
I train them.

If that's what you want to call it. Cat kisses Pepe, taps one of the chimes, it makes the mos ethereal sound as one chime bangs against the other. She opens a cupboard in the makeshift kitchen area, and start unpacking the groceries.
Did you get the beans I like?
Of course.
And the salsa Verde?
And the salsa Verde.
Not the one in the short bottle.
The long one.
I hate that other one, the chili they use sucks. Did you see your  uncle? Of course. She moves from the kitchen, walks across to the far wall.
We're going to church for Easter.
As always.
And you? 67.
Not this year. Until she reaches a big discarded safe, taller than her with an impregnable door.
As always. You should, you know.
I should do a lot of things. She turns the combination knob.
You could start with that one. It would make us very happy.
Maybe next year. The door opens, reveals shelves with dozens of passports, stacks of cash.
Cataleya. No one knows what happens tomorrow, next year is a long time away. How was your trip? Cat starts to remove some of the cash. Starts to count it. Stick it in her pocket.
Rewarding.  She takes a passport out.
Passport?
Your ears are better than my eyes.
You work too much. I keep telling that to Emilio. The girl should have a life while she is still young enough to enjoy it. You should take a vacation. Go some place warm. With a nice beach.
Good idea. She slams the big safe door shut. 68.
From the air, surrounded by the bluest of waters. Bestowe with the greenest of verdant foliage. Surrounded by exquisite beaches. A spray of water fills the screen. Comes from...

head_text.subj: THREE OF THE HOTTEST NYMPHETTES IN THE SMALLEST BIKINIS
SPLASHING AROUND A SWIMMING POOL HAVING THE BEST TIME
SPLASHING WATER AT WILLIAM WOOGARD, AS HE CHASES AFTER

text: An exquisite villa surrounded by a high wall. As the girl clamber out of the pool, ignoring the four armed body gua patrolling poolside, they are met by three maids holding robes for them to slip into.
(SMILING)
Hey! I pay to see more, not less. The robes disappear.
That's better.
Willie you are such a perv.
I know. Anyone hungry?
Always! As William slips into a robe held open for him, he grabs the asses of two of the girls...

Lunch is served. Giggling, the girls scamper toward the villa, where a sumptuous table is set on the veranda, attended by more servants. William is handed a drink, as he sips it, watch their perfect, barely covered butts, his eyes pools of desire, the servant holds out an envelope.
For you sir. 69. Perplexed, William takes his eyes off the girls and regar the envelope. No return address, no stamps. He opens it and his perplexed look goes to one of concern.
It says. SOMEONE IS LOOKING FOR YOU. BE CAREFUL. A FRIEND.
Where did this come from?
It was in the post box this morning. William cannot fathom what this is all about. But he does not like it.
Over hot dance hall music, the sun sets magnificently int the shimmering sea...
The music blasts throughout the villa. Sexy, hot. There are several bodyguards stationed all around.
Two of the girls dance erotically for William, who reclin on an oversized couch, smoking from a hookah.
The third girl is out in the foyer, laying on the glass floor, which is the top of a large aquarium, where dozens of sharks swim back and forth.
Here fishy fishy! She taps on the floor, the sharks ignore her.
(POUTY)
Willie! They're ignoring me! William comes over.

Put a drop of blood in there and they'll be your biggest admirers. All the way down to your stripped clean bones. And speaking of stripped... He lifts her up like a piece of luggage. As she squeals with delight... 70.
Bedtime! The other girls come running. The party moves up the winding staircase. The bodyguards look at each other, roll their eyes.
William is at the double doors to his massive bedroom sui the girls are on the bed in the BG jumping around, in the skimpiest bra and panty sets, having a pillow fight.
(to head of security) Bring extra security in for the night.
Yes sir.
And make sure we're shut down tight.
Yes sir. Have a good night, sir.
I intend to. The doors close, and lock. Wild shrieks come from inside.
A van rolls up to the main gate, half a dozen security me exit.

There are already guys in the garden and guys out back. I want you three upstairs, two on the roof. You three downstairs. Follow me. As they all enter the villa, the CAMERA lingers on the van. A figure dressed in black rolls out from under the carriage as it pulls away and disappears into the bushes.
Two guards stand outside the bedroom door. Two guards are on the stairs. Three guards in the salon. Three more in the garden outside.

The Head of Security goes around the villa checking that all the doors and windows are secure. His men are posted outside the door to the bedroom, on the stairs, in the salon. He closes lights as he goes. 71. He walks across the aquarium floor in the foyer to the front door, closes the lights, so that only the glow from the aquarium lights illuminate the dark. And he exits, closing the door behind him, turning the lock.

The sharks gliding back and forth. And then, a figure in a black wet suit, fins and a mask, with a small back back comes gliding into through the sharks. Who just go about their business. The figure stops at the edge of the glass floor, takes something out of the back pack and very skillfully cuts a small hole in one of the glass panels that makes up the floor. The diver lifts out of the aquarium, pulls back the wet suit. It is Cat. Cat opens the backpack, removes a silencer fitted pistol.

Cat enters, silent, closes the door, approaches the bed where William is asleep sandwiched between the three pass out girls. Empty champagne bottles and glasses are strewn about. Cat stares down at the scene, points her gun at William. One of the girls rolls over onto William, ruining her sho She hesitates.

As sits up suddenly, startled from sleep. No one is in the room. He looks around, and notices the bedroom door ajar. He is more awake now, sees the Nymphettes sleeping soundly. He rises, dressed in a silk sleeping robe. He feels something on his chest, goes over to the mirror, opens his gown and sees, painted on his chest: In red lipstick, the word THIEF, and a drawing of a Cataleya orchid. Panic starts to set in.

Hello? No answer. William tip toes to the ajar door. He peeks out and sees two guards with bullets through their foreheads, blood leaked out across the white marble floor. Really panicked he flattens himself against the inside of the door, his breath coming in gasps.

William, holding the two guns of the dead guards in front of him, makes his way down stairs, past two more dead  guards. Growing more and more nervous by the moment, he tries a light switch on the wall, nothing. 72. The only light comes from the ambient glow of the aquariu below. He reaches the bottom of the stairs.
Anybody? No answer. He crosses the aquarium floor, and when he is right in the middle...
Stop right there. Cat comes out of the dark. In her hand, a silencer fitted pistol.
Who are you?
Doesn't matter who I am. He pulls the trigger on his gun. Click, click, click. He tries the other one. Again click click click.
What do you want?
I want you exactly where you are. And then, without warning, she puts a bullet in both his knees.
He falls to the floor. The blood starts to seep out onto the glass. The sharks swim back and forth.
Whatever they paid you, I'll double it!
You know the thing about sharks. You can swim with them all day and they will just ignore you, but put one drop of blood in the water and  they become your biggest admirers.
Please. I'll give you anything you want. Don't kill me!
I'm not going to kill you. (BEAT)

They are. 73. She fires three shots into the glass square he is kneelin on. The glass shatters. William falls into the water. Grabs onto the squares on either side and props himself up. His blood runs down into the clear water. Cat turns and walks toward the door.
Please! Please! He struggles frantically to pull himself out. Cat exits. And then the sharks hit. WHAM! And hit. And hit. And hit.
Please! Help! Help! He is violently dragged under.
The front page of a newspaper with a picture of the remai of William under the headline: SHARKS EAT SHARK. The newspaper drops to reveal Richard at his desk.
I can't believe this. He drops the paper, is about to leave his office when the phone on his desk rings. He answers.
Yes?
Mr. Steven Richard?
Who is this?
FBI special agent Jack Ross. I'm lead agent on a case. A serial killer we call the tag killer.
Hiding his anger.
I've seen the publicity.
Marks his victims with a flower. From Colombia. A Cataleya orchid. (MORE)
When I try to access information, I get stuck with a CIA Access denied folder. I understand you were the station chief down there when this rash of murders with the same MO...
